title: 114_s2113
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crowdsourcing and Citizen Science Act of 2015". The Congress acknowledges the importance of crowdsourcing and citizen science. The Congress recognizes the benefits of using incentive prizes and challenges by Federal agencies, including paying only for success, setting ambitious goals without predicting the outcome, involving a broader group of people to tackle problems, bringing diverse perspectives, and maximizing cost-effectiveness. The Congress acknowledges the advantages of using incentive prizes and challenges by Federal agencies, such as involving a broader group of people to tackle problems, bringing diverse perspectives, and maximizing cost-effectiveness. Granting Federal agencies the authority to use crowdsourcing and citizen science will remove ambiguity, encourage appropriate use, and stimulate broader public participation in the innovation process. Crowdsourcing projects offer unique benefits, including improving the delivery of government services with lower costs. Crowdsourcing projects offer unique benefits such as improving government service delivery with lower resource investments, connecting citizens to federal agency missions, and acquiring data at a greater geographic extent and frequency than conventional methods. Citizen science promotes open government, volunteerism, and enables citizens to gather, analyze, and share data to address community concerns. It accelerates scientific research through group discovery and diverse perspectives, improves science literacy, and provides skills for excelling in STEM fields. Citizen science promotes open government, volunteerism, and enables citizens to gather, analyze, and share data to address community concerns. It accelerates scientific research through group discovery, diverse perspectives, improves science literacy, and provides skills for excelling in STEM fields. Federal agencies should consider meaningful participation in crowdsourcing and citizen science projects to advance research, improve science literacy, further science diplomacy, and build trust and understanding between citizens and scientists. Federal agencies should consider providing meaningful incentives for participants in crowdsourcing and citizen science projects, such as receiving attribution for contributions, learning new skills, connecting with others, and knowing their work is solving important problems. Participants in crowdsourcing and citizen science projects are motivated by learning new skills, connecting with others, and knowing their work contributes to solving important problems for society. SEC. 3. CROWDSOURCING AND CITIZEN SCIENCE. In this section, "citizen science" involves individuals and organizations collaborating in various ways in the scientific process, while "crowdsourcing" is a method of obtaining services or content by seeking contributions from a group, especially online. The term "crowdsourcing" is defined as a method to obtain services, ideas, or content by soliciting voluntary contributions from a group of individuals or organizations, especially from an online community. The term "Director" refers to the Director of the Office of Science and Technology Policy, and the term "Federal agency" includes Executive agencies and military departments, but excludes legislative branch agencies. The term "participant" refers to individuals or entities volunteering in crowdsourcing or citizen science projects. A "related entity" includes Federal Government contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, users, customers, cooperating parties, grantees, investigators, fellows, or detailees of a Federal agency. Federal agencies can utilize crowdsourcing and citizen science approaches to advance their missions. The head of a Federal agency may accept voluntary services from participants, including Federal Government contractors, subcontractors, suppliers, users, customers, cooperating parties, grantees, investigators, fellows, or detailees of a Federal agency. Federal agencies can accept voluntary services from participants for crowdsourcing or citizen science projects, as long as the services are not financially compensated and do not displace any federal employees. The agencies must also advertise and promote these projects to encourage participation. Each Federal agency engaged in crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must promote and encourage broad participation. Agencies can determine the level of consent, registration, or terms of use required from participants on a project-by-project basis. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must disclose various terms to participants in a clear manner. Consent can be obtained electronically or in writing for volunteer service terms. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects can obtain consent electronically or in written form from participants. Projects involving human subjects must adhere to regulations, and data collected should be made open and available to the public in machine-readable formats. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must make data collected available to the public in machine-readable formats. Participants must be informed of the expected uses of the data, ownership rights, data availability for public use, and their authorization to publish the data. Federal agencies conducting crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must make technologies, applications, code, and derivations of intellectual property developed through the project open and available to the public. Participants must agree to assume risks and waive claims against the Federal Government and its related entities, except for specific claims. Participants in crowdsourcing or citizen science projects must agree to assume risks and waive claims against the Federal Government, except for claims of willful misconduct. Federal agencies coordinating these projects must ensure participants adhere to scientific integrity and ethics policies. Federal agencies coordinating citizen science projects must ensure participants adhere to scientific integrity and ethics policies. Multi-Sector Partnerships allow Federal agencies to share administrative duties with private or public entities. Funding is provided for crowdsourcing and citizen science activities. In carrying out crowdsourcing and citizen science activities, Federal agencies may collaborate with private or public entities for funding and support. Federal agencies can collaborate with various entities for funding and support for crowdsourcing and citizen science activities. The General Services Administration will provide assistance to facilitate the use of these activities within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Special consideration cannot be given to any entity in return for funds or support. The General Services Administration, in coordination with the Director, will develop products and services to support crowdsourcing and citizen science activities within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Federal agencies engaged in these activities are encouraged to consult guidance provided by the Director. A report is required within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Director will report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects conducted by Federal agencies every 4 years as part of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act. The Director will report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects conducted by Federal agencies every 4 years as part of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act. The report will include a summary of each project, participation rates, and project descriptions. The report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 4 years will include goals, participation rates, resources used, and project descriptions. The report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 4 years will include goals, participation rates, resources used, project descriptions, activities, obligations, expenditures, allocation among accounts, ways projects advanced agency mission, project results, data quality methods, and data availability. The report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 4 years will include project results, data quality methods, savings or costs incurred by the Federal Government, and challenges faced by Federal agencies in conducting such projects. The report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 4 years will include project results, data quality methods, savings or costs incurred by the Federal Government, challenges faced by Federal agencies, steps taken to address challenges, recommendations for future action, use of crowdsourcing and citizen science methods by all Federal agencies, interagency partnerships, and any other relevant information. The report on crowdsourcing and citizen science projects by Federal agencies every 4 years will include project results, data quality methods, savings or costs incurred by the Federal Government, challenges faced by Federal agencies, steps taken to address challenges, recommendations for future action, use of crowdsourcing and citizen science methods by all Federal agencies, interagency partnerships, and any other relevant information. Additionally, the Director may include information on the use of crowdsourcing and citizen science methods by Federal agencies, interagency and multi-sector partnerships, and any other relevant details. No provisions in this section should affect the authority to conduct crowdsourcing and citizen science authorized by other laws or displace resources allocated to Federal agencies for these projects.
